messageBody:
Re: Anyone know of a decent debugger?

1. The debugger in CodeWarrior Java for Windows and MacOS is pretty good. The rest of the IDE is not bad, either.

2.
>How do you write tests that cause a database connection to fail after you
>sent the query, but before you got the result back so that the result set
>throws an exception?

In one test, use a mock object that does nothing but throws the desired exception, instead of the real database object. In another test, use another mock object hard-coded to return a desired result set, instead of the real database object.

Refactoring your code to make it easy to use mock objects, also makes the code into a better design.

3.
>This form of debugging requires visual inspection of the debug statements.
>Moreover, logging debug messages at this granularity tends to reduce the
>readability of the code, in my experience.

I agree. Instead of logging statements, write your own Assert class to be used outside of JUnit, and put assertions in your code.

Assert.assertTrue( this.ValidState() );

In the release version, write a handler for Assert exceptions that provides a nice user-interface - at the minumum: "Sorry, unexpected error" + stackcrawl.
